title: WATCH — ‘Rocking my curls:’ How this Montreal teen learned to love her hair
text:
Workshop teaches girls with curly hair how to embrace their natural look

Maybe there are days when you don’t like your hair.

But for 13-year-old Ashley McClair-Thomas, every day with her hair felt like a challenge.

Growing up in Montreal, the teen — who has a black mom and a white dad — said she doesn’t have a lot of role models who embrace their curly hair and most of the kids at her school have straight hair.

“I would try to blend in with kids who didn’t have curly hair,” she told CBC Kids News.

That all changed after she attended a workshop run by a hairstylist named Nancy Falaise.

Ashley McClair-Thomas, 13, now wears her hair curly with confidence, thanks to what she learned at a workshop in Montreal. (Submitted by Ashley McClair-Thomas)

Falaise’s workshop is held monthly for girls with curly hair in Montreal.

It helps them learn to embrace their natural hair texture by teaching them the right technique.

“I just feel so much more confident rocking my curls,” Ashley said following her experience at the workshop.

The story behind Falaise’s workshop has been turned into a documentary by Canesugar Filmworks and is streaming on CBC Gem.

Ashley’s story is not unique

Black women have struggled for decades to find ways to embrace their natural hair, said A’lelia Bundles, a black author and journalist.

That’s because “we live in a culture where European beauty standards are dominant,” she said.

Bundles wrote a book about C.J. Walker, her great-great grandmother, who started one of the first lines of beauty products for curly hair more than one hundred years ago.

“Not only is our skin colour different (...) but our hair texture is different,” said Bundles, from her office in Washington, D.C.

A’lelia Bundles has worn her hair in different styles over the years, including an afro in the 1960’s. Her great-great-grandmother was one of the first people to develop products specifically for women with curly hair. (Larry French/Getty Images)

She herself has observed discrimination in the U.S. against black kids because of their curly hair.

“There are schools that have rules against afro puffs,” she said. “They say it’s distracting. But nobody is saying that about a little girl who has ponytails.”

As a result, some black women and girls feel pressured to straighten their hair or wear it pulled back, rather than leave it loose and curly.

Ashley’s journey

In Ashley’s case, she said she often felt insecure about her hair before attending the workshop, and always wore it slicked back in a bun.

“I would try to blend in with kids who didn't have curly hair. I didn't want to like, make a big scene,” she said.

“I felt like having like big, big hair was scary or that it was just ugly. I never liked it, I always liked straight hair, perfectly cut and everything.”

Ashley said she wanted to attend the workshop to learn how to love her hair “and be grateful and proud of having my hair and my natural curls.”

Ashley recently attended a workshop where she learned how to care for her curls. (Nancy’s Workshop/Canesugar Filmworks)

Over the course of an afternoon at Falaise’s Montreal salon, girls learned how to wash, detangle and style their hair.

Ashley said helping other girls with their hair — and having them help her — was “really special.”

Having done the workshop, Ashley said she sees her ‘do in a different light.

“My hair feels healthy, my hair feels beautiful. I feel amazing.”

Now, she’s paying those lessons forward, by teaching her 11-year-old sister Hailey how to style her curly hair.

Ashley is helping her 11-year-old sister Hailey learn to love her hair. (Submitted by Ashley McClair-Thomas)

Hailey said she used to look at celebrities and wish her hair was straight like theirs, thinking that it would be easier to manage.

With Ashley’s help, though, Hailey is starting to love her hair.

“I think it looks really good, and I really think that I could go out in public like this and be really confident,” she said.

Ashley said her hair transformation has also inspired her friends with curly hair to try different styles.

She hopes that even more kids will feel inspired by her experience to embrace their natural hair.

“They should feel encouraged to help each other with their curly hair and talk about the struggles, talk about the things they like and just make it a topic.”
description: A teen from Montreal has learned to embrace her curly hair thanks to a workshop that teaches girls the best techniques for curly hair.
